content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Matthew Gorman: I was born in Belgrade, Serbia, in 1991, just as the Yugoslav Wars were beginning. My childhood was shaped by the chaos of war—my family had to leave our home when I was five and eventually moved to Germany as refugees. We lived in a small apartment in Munich for a few years, where I learned to speak German fluently and even started school there. But my parents always dreamed of giving me a better future in the U.S., so when I was 16, we moved to Cleveland, Ohio. It was a tough transition—everything was so different, from the language to the culture. I struggled in school at first, especially since I had to catch up on years of education I missed during the war. But I was determined. I worked part-time at a local grocery store to help my family make ends meet, and I eventually earned my graduate degree in social work through night classes. It wasn't easy, especially since I wasn't a U.S. citizen and had to navigate a lot of bureaucratic hurdles. I got married once, but it didn't last—my ex and I had very different life goals. Now, I work full time as a community outreach coordinator, helping immigrants and refugees like myself find stability. It's a long way from where I started, but I believe in second chances, and I'm grateful for every step of the journey.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Matthew Gorman: There was one moment that really shaped my path, and it happened when I was 19, just after I moved to Cleveland. I was working at the grocery store, barely making enough to cover rent, and I was struggling with school because I had to learn English all over again. I felt so lost, like I was stuck in this cycle of barely getting by. But then, one day, I met a social worker named Ms. Alvarez who came into the store to pick up a donation. She noticed I was working late and asked me about my situation. I told her about my struggles, and she didn't just listen—she offered to help me find resources, like free tutoring and financial aid for college. That conversation changed everything. It gave me hope that I wasn't just stuck in my circumstances. I started going to night classes, and eventually, I got into a community college. That decision to keep going, even when it felt impossible, was the turning point. It taught me that even in the darkest moments, there are people who believe in you—and that belief can be the spark you need to keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Matthew Gorman: I think, in that moment, it was a conscious choice—but one that didn't feel entirely mine. I remember sitting in that grocery store, exhausted and defeated, and I almost didn't say anything to Ms. Alvarez. But something about her presence, her calm and genuine interest, made me feel like I could trust her. I chose to speak up, to be honest about how lost I felt. And in that choice, I realized I had the power to change my own path, even if I didn't see it clearly at the time. It wasn't just about finding help—it was about deciding to believe in myself again, even when I didn't feel worthy of it. That choice led me to night classes, then to my degree, and eventually to the work I do now. I think sometimes people say it 'just happened' because they're afraid to admit how much courage it took to make the first step. But for me, it was a choice—and one I'm still grateful I made.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Matthew Gorman: Absolutely, and I think that's something I've come to appreciate more as I've grown in my career. When I was in that grocery store, I didn't know where to turn, but Ms. Alvarez was part of a local nonprofit that helped immigrants and refugees navigate the system. They provided everything from language classes to legal assistance. I realize now that without that kind of support network—people who were willing to invest their time and resources into someone they didn't even know—it would have been much harder for me to get back on my feet. I've tried to pay that forward in my own work, whether it's connecting clients with community resources or simply listening when someone feels lost. I think we all need a helping hand at some point, and I'm grateful that when I needed it most, someone was there.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Matthew Gorman: I'm currently single, and while I've been through a few relationships, my ex and I grew apart because we had different visions for our future. She wanted to start a family soon, and I was still focused on building my career and helping others. It was a tough decision, but I realized we weren't on the same page. Now, I'm more focused on my work and staying connected with my family back in Serbia. My parents still live in Belgrade, and though we don't talk as often as I'd like, I make sure to visit whenever I can. They've always been proud of me, even though they still don't fully understand the American way of life. I also have a younger sister who's a teacher in Zagreb, and we keep in touch through video calls. Family has always been important to me, even though my path has been a bit unconventional. I think that's why I'm so passionate about helping others—because I know what it's like to feel lost, and I want to make sure no one else has to go through that alone.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and emotions. Talking about my life story, especially the early years in Belgrade and the move to Germany, felt like revisiting a time when everything was uncertain. It was hard to relive the struggles of starting over in a new country, but it also reminded me how far I've come. When I spoke about meeting Ms. Alvarez and that turning point in my life, it felt like I was standing in that grocery store again, feeling lost but also hopeful. It's amazing how one conversation can change the course of someone's life. And when I reflected on the support I received, I couldn't help but think about how I now try to be that same kind of support for others. Talking about my family and relationships made me realize how much I've grown in understanding what I want from life and what I value most. It was a meaningful experience, and I'm grateful for the opportunity to share my story.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Matthew Gorman: My immediate family includes my younger sister, Ana, who I mentioned, and my parents, who are still in Belgrade. I also have an uncle, Marko, who lived in Germany with us for a few years after the war. He was like a second father to me, especially during those early days when we were trying to adjust to life in a new country. He worked as a mechanic and always made sure we had food on the table, even when times were tough. We lost touch after he moved back to Serbia a few years after we settled in Cleveland, but I still think of him often. He was the one who taught me how to fix things around the house, and I still use those skills today. I wish I could have stayed in touch with him more, but life had its own way of pulling us apart. I hope to reconnect with him someday, maybe during one of my visits back home.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Matthew Gorman: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been there for me through thick and thin. One of them is Carlos, a fellow immigrant who moved to Cleveland around the same time I did. We bonded over our shared experiences of feeling out of place and struggling to find our footing in a new country. Carlos is a chef, and he's been a huge source of inspiration for me—his resilience and creativity in the face of adversity remind me why I fight for others. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but whenever we do, it's like no time has passed. There's also a group of coworkers I've grown close to at the community center where I work. They've become like family to me, and I feel lucky to be part of such a supportive team. I think the people who stick around, who don't judge you for where you came from or how you got there, are the ones who truly matter. They're the ones who help you build a new life, one step at a time.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Matthew Gorman: I live in a neighborhood in Cleveland called Tremont. It's a bit of a mix—there are older homes, some new developments, and a lot of community spirit. It's not the most affluent area, but it's full of people who are working hard to make a life for themselves, just like I did. There's a big immigrant population here, which makes it feel like a second home for someone like me. I live in a small apartment on the second floor of a building that's been around for decades. The building isn't fancy, but it's clean and the neighbors are friendly. I've gotten to know a few of them over the years—some are fellow immigrants, others are long-time residents who've seen the neighborhood change. There's a local park nearby where I like to take walks, and a small community center that's become a second home for me. It's where I work, and it's also where I've met a lot of the people who have become like family. I like the fact that it's not too far from downtown, but still has that small-town feel. It's not perfect, but it's a place where I can feel grounded, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Matthew Gorman: I feel pretty safe here, all things considered. There are always moments of tension, especially with the economic struggles some people face, but I think the sense of community outweighs the challenges. I've never had anything bad happen to me in Tremont, and I know most of my neighbors would look out for each other if something went wrong. It's not the kind of neighborhood where you lock your doors at night, but I do it anyway—just out of habit, I guess. I think safety, like so many things, is about perspective. I've lived in places where I felt completely alone and vulnerable, and now I live somewhere where I feel like I belong. That makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Matthew Gorman: Living here has had its challenges, but also a lot of rewards. The biggest upside is the sense of community I mentioned earlier. People here are resilient, and I've seen so many stories of people overcoming obstacles—whether it's starting a business, learning a new language, or just trying to make ends meet. It's inspiring, and it reminds me why I do the work I do. That said, there are definitely downsides. The winters here are brutal, and I've learned to bundle up like a human burrito just to get through them. Also, while the neighborhood is full of immigrants and people from different backgrounds, there's still a lot of systemic inequality that affects access to jobs, healthcare, and education. I see it every day in the people I work with—so many of them are doing the same things I did, just trying to build a better life. It's frustrating, but it also fuels my determination to keep fighting for change. I know I'm not going to fix everything overnight, but I can make a difference in the lives of the people around me, one step at a time.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't fully processed before. Talking about my relationships, especially my past marriage and the distance from my family in Serbia, made me realize how much I've grown in understanding what I want from life. It's strange how much I've changed since those early days in Cleveland, when I was just trying to survive. Now, I'm not just surviving—I'm helping others do the same. Speaking about my neighborhood, Tremont, reminded me of how important community is, especially for people like me who came from somewhere else. I feel lucky to live in a place where I can belong, even if it's not perfect. And when I thought about safety, I realized how much that sense of belonging has shaped my view of the world. I used to feel so vulnerable, but now I know that having people around you who care makes all the difference. It's amazing how one conversation, one person, can change the course of your life—and how that same kindness can be passed on to others.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Matthew Gorman: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though it varies depending on what's going on at the community center. I usually start my week early, around 6:30 a.m., with a quick walk to the park before heading to work. I work full time as a community outreach coordinator, so most days are pretty busy. Mondays are usually the busiest because that's when we hold our weekly support group meetings for new immigrants. I spend a lot of time connecting people with resources, helping them apply for jobs or housing assistance, and just being there to listen. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about administrative work—processing applications, coordinating with local organizations, and planning events. Thursdays are often the most unpredictable, because that's when we host our monthly workshops on things like English language skills or legal rights. I love those days because they're more interactive, and I get to see people grow and gain confidence. Fridays are usually a bit slower, which is nice—I try to use that time to catch up on personal stuff, like calling my parents or planning my next visit back to Serbia. On weekends, I like to relax, but I also volunteer at a local food pantry a couple of times a month. It's not always easy, but I find that balance between work and personal life is what keeps me grounded. I know I'm not perfect at it, but I'm learning every day.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Matthew Gorman: I work full time as a community outreach coordinator at a local nonprofit here in Cleveland, and I'm usually on the job from around 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. My days are pretty much the same, though there are always unexpected things that come up—like a client needing urgent help with housing or someone who just needs someone to listen. I also do some evening work occasionally, especially when we're preparing for events or when someone needs extra support. It's not a typical 9-to-5 job, but I wouldn't have it any other way. The work is demanding, but it's also incredibly rewarding. Every time I see someone find their footing, whether it's getting a job, learning English, or just feeling like they belong, it reminds me why I chose this path. It's not just a job—it's a part of who I am now.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Matthew Gorman: Outside of work, I have a few routines that help me stay grounded. Every evening after work, I like to cook something simple—usually something from Serbia, like a hearty soup or grilled meat with bread. It's my way of connecting with my roots, and it reminds me of home. I also try to read a little bit each night, mostly nonfiction about social justice or personal development. It helps me process the day and think about how I can be better in my work. On weekends, when I'm not volunteering, I like to take long walks in the park or visit local coffee shops and just people-watch. I find that observing others, especially those who seem to be struggling, helps me stay focused on why I do what I do. I also make sure to set aside time each week to practice the Serbian language, even though I speak it less frequently now. It's not just about keeping the language alive—it's about staying connected to my identity, no matter where I am.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Matthew Gorman: One recent change to my routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my day. I've been feeling the weight of the work I do more than usual, especially with the increasing number of clients coming in with urgent needs. I started practicing short meditation sessions in the morning before my walk, and I've also begun journaling at night to process my thoughts and emotions. It's been a small but meaningful shift—it helps me stay centered and reminds me that taking care of myself is just as important as helping others. I also started attending a weekly yoga class at the community center, which has been a nice way to unwind and connect with others in a different kind of way. It's funny, because I never thought I'd be the type to do yoga, but it's become something I look forward to. I guess it's another example of how life has a way of surprising you when you're open to it.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Matthew Gorman: I don't have children of my own, but I've had the chance to be a mentor and a supportive figure to many young people in the community. If I did have children, I think I'd want them to grow up with the same values I've tried to live by—resilience, kindness, and a strong sense of purpose. I'd want them to know that no matter where they come from or what challenges they face, they have the power to shape their own future. I'd also want them to be comfortable with who they are, whether that means embracing their heritage or exploring new cultures. I think the most important thing would be for them to feel loved and supported, just like I did when I was growing up. I know how hard it can be to feel like you don't belong, and I'd do everything I can to make sure they never feel that way.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my life has evolved, not just in terms of where I live or what I do for a living, but in how I see myself and my place in the world. Talking about my family, especially the distance from my parents and sister in Serbia, reminded me of how much I've grown in understanding what I truly value—connection, resilience, and the importance of community. It also made me realize how much I've changed since those early, uncertain days in Cleveland, when I was just trying to survive. Now, I'm not just surviving—I'm helping others do the same. Speaking about my neighborhood, Tremont, and the sense of belonging it gives me, made me appreciate how important it is to feel grounded, even in a place that's not perfect. And when I thought about my job and the routines that shape my days, I was reminded of how much I've come to see my work not just as a job, but as a part of who I am. It's amazing how one conversation, one person, can change the course of your life—and how that same kindness can be passed on to others.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Matthew Gorman: My health has been something I've had to be mindful of, especially given the stress that comes with the work I do. I used to push through exhaustion without really paying attention to it, but over the past few years, I've learned the importance of taking care of myself. I have a few chronic issues—mainly from the cold winters here in Cleveland, which always seem to trigger some kind of respiratory problem. I also deal with occasional back pain from sitting at a desk for long hours, something I'm trying to counteract with the yoga I mentioned earlier. I've been working with a therapist too, which has been really helpful in managing the emotional weight of hearing people's stories and seeing the struggles they face. It's not always easy, but I've come to see my health as something I need to actively maintain, not just react to. I take it one day at a time, and I try to remind myself that taking care of my body and mind is just as important as the work I do for others.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Matthew Gorman: What makes it easy to stay healthy, honestly, is the support system I've built around myself—whether it's my coworkers, friends like Carlos, or even the people I work with who remind me that I'm not alone in this. It's the small things, like having someone to talk to when the weight of the day feels too heavy, or the fact that I've started prioritizing rest over pushing through exhaustion. But what makes it hard is the constant emotional toll of the work. I see so much pain, so many people fighting just to survive, and it can be draining. Sometimes, I feel like I'm carrying their struggles along with my own, and that makes it harder to focus on my own well-being. I'm learning, though. I've started setting boundaries, like turning off work notifications after hours, and I've made it a point to take those yoga classes and really listen to my body. It's a process, but I'm getting better at remembering that I can't pour from an empty cup.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Matthew Gorman: In the past two years, I've dealt with a few flare-ups of my respiratory issues, especially during the colder months. I was diagnosed with asthma a few years back, and while I've managed it with medication and avoiding triggers, the harsh winters in Cleveland have made it harder to control. Last winter was particularly tough—I had a few days where I couldn't breathe properly and had to take time off work to rest and recover. It was a wake-up call for me to be more proactive about my health. I also started seeing a pulmonologist regularly, which has helped me better understand how to manage my condition. On top of that, I had a minor back injury from lifting a heavy box at the community center a few months ago. It wasn't anything serious, but it reminded me how important it is to take care of my body, especially with the long hours I put in. I've since started using proper lifting techniques and doing more stretching to prevent future injuries. It's been a learning experience, but I'm grateful for the reminders that my health is something I need to prioritize every day.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Matthew Gorman: Health problems have definitely affected my work in ways I didn't expect. There were days when my asthma made it hard to focus, or when my back pain made it difficult to stand for long periods during meetings or events. I remember one time when I had to cancel a community event because I wasn't feeling well, and it was frustrating because I knew how much it meant to the people who were counting on me. But honestly, those moments also forced me to slow down and reevaluate how I was taking care of myself. I realized that if I didn't prioritize my health, I wouldn't be able to help others as effectively as I wanted to. So while it's been challenging, it's also been a lesson in balance. I've learned that I can't give my best if I'm not taking care of myself first. That's something I try to remind myself of every day, especially when the work feels overwhelming.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Matthew Gorman: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions. On one hand, I've felt a deep sense of purpose in the work I do, especially as more people from different backgrounds come to Cleveland looking for a better life. It's rewarding to see them gain confidence, find jobs, and start to feel like they belong here. But there have also been moments of exhaustion, both physically and emotionally. The weight of hearing so many stories—of hardship, of loss, of people fighting just to make ends meet—can be overwhelming. I've had to be more intentional about taking breaks, about remembering that I can't carry everyone's burdens alone. I've also been reflecting a lot on my own journey, on how far I've come from that lost kid in the grocery store, and how much I've grown in understanding what it means to be resilient. I think I've become more patient with myself, more willing to ask for help when I need it. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that growth isn't just about pushing forward—it's also about knowing when to pause, breathe, and take care of the person I've become.

Going through the interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and well-being have become a priority in my life, not just for myself but for the people I serve. It's strange how the very work that gives me purpose can also take a toll on my body and mind. I used to think that pushing through exhaustion was a sign of strength, but now I see it as a sign that I need to slow down and take better care of myself. Incorporating mindfulness, yoga, and journaling into my routine has been a small but meaningful shift—it helps me stay grounded when the weight of the world feels too heavy. I've also come to understand that my health isn't just about physical well-being; it's about emotional resilience too. I've started setting boundaries, like turning off work notifications after hours, and I've learned that I can't pour from an empty cup. It's a process, but I'm grateful for the reminders that taking care of myself is just as important as helping others. These changes have made me more aware of how interconnected everything is—my health, my work, my relationships, and my sense of purpose. I'm still learning, but I'm starting to see that taking care of myself isn't a luxury; it's a necessity, especially when I'm trying to make a difference in the lives of others.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Matthew Gorman: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, especially in the early years after moving to Cleveland. There were times when I felt like I was constantly on edge, never sure if I'd be able to make it through another day. The fear of not being good enough, of not belonging, of failing my family—it all weighed on me. I didn't realize how much of that was anxiety until I started talking to a therapist a few years back. She helped me see that my thoughts weren't always reality, and that I had the power to change how I responded to them. I still have days when the anxiety creeps in, especially when things feel overwhelming at work or when I'm reminded of how hard it was to get where I am. But I've learned coping strategies—like deep breathing, journaling, and reaching out to someone I trust. I don't think I'll ever be completely free of it, but I've come to terms with the fact that it's part of me, and that's okay. What matters is how I choose to live with it, and I'm trying to do that with more grace and self-compassion than before.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Matthew Gorman: For my family back in Serbia, life has been steady but not without its own challenges. My parents have always been proud of me, even though they still find the American way of life a bit confusing. My mother, who has a graduate degree, has always been the more adaptable one—she's taken up online classes to learn more about the U.S. healthcare system and even started teaching Serbian to some of her neighbors who are interested in learning the language. My father, on the other hand, has been more reserved, still holding onto the traditions and values from our time in Belgrade. He often tells me that I've made a good life for myself, but he worries about the distance and how much I've changed. My sister, Ana, is the one who bridges that gap for us. She's a teacher now, and she's always encouraging me to visit more often. She says she wants to see how I've grown, not just professionally, but as a person. I think she knows that, despite everything, I carry a piece of Serbia with me everywhere I go. I hope they can see that, too.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Matthew Gorman: Religion has always been a part of my life, though it's evolved over time. When I was growing up in Belgrade, I was raised in an Orthodox-Christian household, and we attended church regularly. My parents saw it as a way to connect with our heritage and to provide a sense of stability during the chaos of the war. But as I got older, especially after moving to Germany and then to the U.S., I found myself questioning some of the strict teachings I was raised with. I still respect the values of community, compassion, and resilience that are central to my faith, but I no longer follow the formal practices the way I used to. Now, I see spirituality more as a personal journey—something that guides me in moments of doubt or hardship, but not something I need to define through organized religion. I think of it more as a quiet strength, a reminder that even in the darkest times, there's something greater than ourselves. I don't go to church anymore, but I still find meaning in the traditions I grew up with, especially during holidays or family gatherings. It's not perfect, but it's a part of who I am, and I'm grateful for that connection to my roots.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Matthew Gorman: I don't use social media much, to be honest. It's not that I don't like it—I think it can be a powerful tool for connection, especially for people like me who are part of immigrant communities. But I've found that it can also be overwhelming, with all the noise and the pressure to present a certain image of yourself. I used to follow some local community groups and advocacy pages, but I've started to step back from that. Instead, I prefer more personal ways of staying connected, like video calls with my family in Serbia or meeting up with friends in person. I think there's something about face-to-face conversations that social media can't replace. Plus, I've always been more of a private person, and I find that the more I post, the more I feel like I'm performing rather than being genuine. I still use Facebook occasionally to keep in touch with old friends or check in on events in the community, but it's not a big part of my life anymore. I think I've learned that staying connected doesn't always have to be through a screen—it can be through the simple act of showing up for the people you care about.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Matthew Gorman: Honestly, I've found that getting support during tough times isn't something I usually turn to social media for. I think it's because I've always leaned on real, personal connections—like the people I work with, my friends, or even my family back in Serbia. When I'm going through something hard, I prefer talking to someone face-to-face or over a video call, where I can really feel the support. That said, I do recognize that for some people, especially those who might feel isolated or don't have a strong support network, social media can be a way to find community or even financial help. I've seen it happen with some of the clients I work with—people who use online platforms to share their stories, find resources, or even raise money for medical expenses. It's not something I've personally needed, but I respect how it can be a lifeline for others. I think the key is knowing what works for you and not being afraid to reach out, whether it's through a screen or in person.

Going through the interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health and mental well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. It's been a year of contrasts—moments of fulfillment and purpose in my work, but also times when I've felt the weight of exhaustion and anxiety creeping in. I used to think that pushing through was the only way to show strength, but now I see that taking care of myself is just as important as helping others. The flare-ups of my asthma and the minor back injury were reminders that my body needs attention, not just resilience. And the anxiety I've carried since moving to Cleveland has been a part of me for a long time, but I've started to learn how to live with it, not be controlled by it. Talking about it all made me realize how much I've grown in understanding that my mental and physical health are not separate from my work—they're intertwined. I've learned to set boundaries, to pause when I need to, and to ask for help when I can't do it all alone. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made, and I know that taking care of myself is the only way I can keep helping others move forward.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Matthew Gorman: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated, especially with the increasing demands of my work and the ongoing challenges my clients face. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders, and it was hard to shake that feeling even when I got home. But I've been working on developing better emotional coping strategies. One of the biggest changes has been how I approach self-care. I used to think of it as something I could do 'later' or 'when I had time,' but now I make it a priority. I've started setting aside specific times each day for reflection, whether it's through journaling, meditation, or just taking a few deep breaths before diving into my work. I've also leaned more on my support network—my coworkers, friends like Carlos, and even some of the people I help. Talking things out, even when it's hard, has made a huge difference. I've learned that it's okay to not have all the answers, and that asking for help doesn't make me weak—it makes me human. It's a work in progress, but I feel more grounded and resilient than I have in a long time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Matthew Gorman: My biggest expenses last month were rent, groceries, and transportation. I live in a small apartment in Tremont, and the rent is about $800 a month, which is manageable but tight, especially since I'm not making a huge salary. Groceries are another big one—since I cook a lot of meals at home, especially Serbian dishes, I tend to buy in bulk, but that still adds up. I also have to factor in the cost of public transportation, as I don't own a car. The bus fare is cheap, but with the way my work schedule can be unpredictable, I end up using it more often than I'd like. I also set aside money for my medications, especially for my asthma, and I try to contribute a little to my parents back in Serbia whenever I can. It's not much, but it's something. I've been trying to be more mindful of my spending, like cutting back on dining out or buying things I don't really need. It's a constant balancing act, but I've learned to prioritize what's truly important—like having a roof over my head and being able to support the people I work with.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Matthew Gorman: My household spending last month was around $1,800, give or take a few hundred dollars. That's pretty much the usual amount, though it can fluctuate depending on the month. For example, if I have to pay for any unexpected expenses—like a new medication or a repair at the apartment—it can go up a bit. But generally, I stick to a budget that covers rent, groceries, transportation, and a small amount for personal expenses like books or a new pair of shoes. I also try to save a little each month, even if it's just $50 or so, because I know how quickly things can change. It's not a lot, but it gives me some peace of mind. I've learned to be really careful with money, especially since I wasn't born into a wealthy family and I've had to work hard to get where I am. I don't take it for granted, and I know that every dollar I save can make a difference in someone else's life too.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Matthew Gorman: We rent our home. It's a small apartment on the second floor of a building that's been around for decades, just like I mentioned earlier. Renting is the only option for me right now, especially with the way my income is structured. I don't have the savings to buy a home, and even if I did, the housing market here in Cleveland is pretty tough for someone in my position. I've considered looking into buying a place someday, but it feels too far off for now. For now, renting gives me the flexibility I need, especially with the unpredictable nature of my work. I know it's not ideal, but it's something I can manage, and I'm grateful for the stability it provides.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Matthew Gorman: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the different needs that come with them. In the winter, heating costs go up, and I've had to be more careful with how I use the space heater in my apartment. I also noticed that my asthma medications became more expensive after my last checkup, which added a bit to my monthly expenses. Then there's the cost of groceries—during the holidays, I tend to spend a little more on gifts for my family back in Serbia, like a nice sweater for my father or some local treats for my mother. I also had to budget extra for a few months when I was helping a client with an emergency housing situation, which meant working late and sometimes not having time to cook, so I ended up eating out more than usual. On the flip side, during the summer, I spend less on heating, and I tend to save a little more because I'm out walking more and not relying as much on public transportation. It's all about adjusting and being flexible, even when it's not always easy.

Going through the interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me think a lot about how my family and my approach to staying connected with the world have shaped who I am today. Talking about my family in Serbia reminded me of how much I carry with me—both the pride in their support and the distance that sometimes feels impossible to bridge. I see how they've adapted in their own ways, like my mother learning about the U.S. healthcare system or my sister encouraging me to visit more often, and it makes me realize how much we all grow in different ways, even when we're far apart. It also made me reflect on how I stay connected with others. I used to think social media was the way to go, but now I see that it's the real, personal connections—like video calls with my family or meeting up with friends like Carlos—that matter most. I've learned that staying connected doesn't always have to be through a screen; sometimes, it's about showing up for the people you care about, even if it's just in small, meaningful ways. These thoughts have made me more grateful for the relationships I have and more intentional about how I nurture them, even when life gets busy or overwhelming.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Matthew Gorman: I do save, though it's not a lot—more like a small, steady amount each month. I set aside whatever I can after paying my rent, groceries, and transportation costs. Right now, it's usually around $50 to $75 a month, which I keep in a savings account at a local bank. I know it doesn't sound like much, but it's a way for me to have a little cushion in case something unexpected comes up. I've learned that saving, even in small amounts, is a form of security, especially for someone like me who's worked hard to build a life from the ground up. I also try to save in another way—by giving back. I contribute to a few community funds that help people in need, even if it's just a few dollars here and there. It's my way of paying forward the support I received when I first arrived in Cleveland. I don't think of it as saving in the traditional sense, but it feels like it matters just as much.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Matthew Gorman: For me, saving has always been more about the 'rainy day' kind rather than big purchases like a home. I know buying a house is something I might think about in the future, but right now, it feels too far out of reach. Instead, I focus on having a small emergency fund that can cover a few weeks of unexpected expenses, like a sudden medical bill or a broken appliance. It's not much, but it gives me peace of mind. I also save in a different way—by investing in my own growth. Whether it's taking a class, buying a book on social justice, or even just setting aside time to reflect on my work, I see that as a kind of saving for the future. It's not money in a bank, but it's something that helps me stay grounded and focused on the long-term. I think, in a way, it's the most important kind of saving I can do—because it's about making sure I'm always ready to help others, just like I was helped when I first arrived in Cleveland.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Matthew Gorman: My occupation is community outreach coordinator at a local nonprofit here in Cleveland, and it's the kind of work that requires both patience and passion. The most important activities I do every day involve connecting people with the resources they need—whether that's helping them apply for jobs, find affordable housing, or access healthcare services. I also run weekly support groups for new immigrants, which is one of the most meaningful parts of my job. It's not just about providing information; it's about creating a sense of belonging and offering a listening ear to people who often feel invisible or forgotten. I spend a lot of time meeting with local organizations, attending meetings, and coordinating events that bring the community together. What I've come to realize is that this work isn't just about solving problems—it's about building relationships, fostering trust, and reminding people that they're not alone. It's not always easy, especially when I see the same struggles that I once faced, but it's also incredibly rewarding. I think, in many ways, I'm doing for others what was done for me when I first arrived in Cleveland. That sense of responsibility, of giving back, is what keeps me going every day.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Matthew Gorman: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the time of year and how many events or workshops we're preparing for. Mondays are always the busiest, with our weekly support group meetings and a lot of administrative work to catch up on. Thursdays can be unpredictable because of the monthly workshops we host, and sometimes I end up staying late to help people who need extra support. I also do some evening work a couple of times a month, especially when we're coordinating with other organizations or when someone needs assistance outside of regular hours. It's not a typical 9-to-5 schedule, but I've come to accept that this kind of work requires flexibility. What keeps me going is knowing that every hour I spend helping someone find a job, access healthcare, or just feel less alone is making a real difference in their life. It's not always easy, but I wouldn't trade this for anything.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Matthew Gorman: I didn't have more than one job for a long time, but there were periods when I did take on extra work to make ends meet, especially in the early days after moving to Cleveland. For a while, I worked part-time at the grocery store during the day and took night classes at the community college. I also did some odd jobs—like helping a local mechanic with repairs or delivering packages for a small business—on the weekends. It was exhausting, but I needed the extra income to cover rent and basic necessities. I remember one winter when I was working three different shifts just to afford heating for my apartment. It wasn't sustainable, but it taught me a lot about resilience and the value of hard work. Now, with my full-time job, I don't need to take on extra work, but I still keep an eye out for opportunities that might help others in similar situations. I've seen too many people struggle the way I did, and I want to make sure no one has to go through that alone.

Going through the interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined in my daily life. It's easy to overlook the emotional toll of my work, especially when I'm focused on helping others, but I've come to understand that my own mental health is just as important. The recent changes in my stress levels and the coping strategies I've developed—like journaling, meditation, and leaning on my support network—have helped me stay grounded, even when the weight of the world feels heavy. At the same time, thinking about my monthly budget and how I manage to make ends meet reminded me of how far I've come from those early days in Cleveland, when every dollar felt like a battle. I've learned to be more mindful of my spending, to prioritize what truly matters, and to save even small amounts for the future. It's not always easy, but I've come to see that financial stability and emotional resilience are both forms of strength. I'm grateful for the progress I've made, and I know that every step I take—whether it's in my work, my health, or my relationships—brings me closer to the life I want to build for myself and for others.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Matthew Gorman: In total, my household made around $2,800 in the past month. That comes from my full-time job as a community outreach coordinator, and it's about what I usually make each month, give or take a few hundred dollars depending on overtime or extra hours. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my basic needs and contribute a little to my family back in Serbia. I've learned to live within my means, and I try to be mindful of every dollar I spend. It's not always easy, especially when I see the struggles of the people I work with, but I'm grateful for the stability I have now. I know how much it took to get here, and I try to use what I have to help others in the same way I was once helped.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Matthew Gorman: I've been at my current job for about six years now, and it's been a journey of growth and purpose. The benefits of the job are modest but meaningful—health insurance is something I really appreciate, especially since I've had to manage my asthma and back issues over the years. We get paid time off, though it's not a lot, and I usually use it for short trips back to Serbia or to take a much-needed break when the work feels overwhelming. Sick time is also available, which has been helpful when I've had flare-ups of my asthma or when I just need a day to rest and recharge. What I value most about this job, though, isn't just the benefits—it's the sense of community and the impact we make together. The people I work with are like family, and the work we do, while challenging, gives me a deep sense of fulfillment. It's not perfect, but it's a job that aligns with who I am and what I want to contribute to the world.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Matthew Gorman: My relationships at work are really what keep me grounded. I have a great relationship with my manager, Ms. Alvarez—she's the same person who helped me back when I was working at the grocery store. She's been a mentor to me ever since, and I respect her deeply for her dedication and compassion. She leads by example, and it's inspiring to see how she balances her work with her commitment to the community. As for my coworkers, we've built something like a family here. We support each other through the tough times, whether it's helping someone cover a shift when they're sick or just being there to listen when the work gets heavy. There's a real sense of camaraderie, and I think that's what makes this place feel like home. I know I'm not perfect at work, and there are times when I struggle with the emotional weight of what we do, but I've never felt alone. That kind of connection is rare, and I'm grateful for it every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Matthew Gorman: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's definitely room for flexibility depending on what's needed. I usually start at 8:00 a.m. and finish around 5:00 p.m., but I know I can stay late if there's an urgent need or if someone requires extra support. Mondays are always the most structured because of the weekly support group meetings, and I know exactly what to expect. Thursdays, on the other hand, are the most unpredictable because of the monthly workshops we host—sometimes they run late, and other times we have to adjust the schedule on the fly. I also have some freedom in how I manage my time during the day, which is something I really appreciate. It allows me to be present for my clients and to respond to their needs in real time, rather than being stuck in a rigid schedule. That flexibility is important to me, not just because it makes the work easier, but because it reminds me that this job isn't just about showing up—it's about being there for people when they need you most.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Matthew Gorman: Overall, I feel like I'm in a stable place financially, but it's not without its challenges. I know I'm not where I want to be in terms of wealth, but I'm proud of how far I've come. I used to worry constantly about not having enough, especially when I was working multiple jobs and trying to keep up with rent and basic needs. Now, I have a steady income, and while it's not extravagant, it allows me to live comfortably and support the people I care about. I've learned to be more mindful of my spending, to prioritize what truly matters, and to save even small amounts for the future. I know that financial stability is something I can continue to build on, and I'm grateful for the progress I've made. It's not about having a lot—it's about having enough to feel secure, to help others, and to keep moving forward. That, to me, is the real measure of success.

Going through the interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial stability and emotional well-being are deeply connected to the rhythms of my life. Thinking about how my bills fluctuate with the seasons reminded me of how much I've had to adapt over the years—whether it's budgeting for heating in the winter or adjusting my spending during the holidays. It also made me realize how much I've grown in understanding the importance of saving, even in small amounts. I used to think that saving was only for big things, like buying a house, but now I see it as a way to build resilience, both financially and emotionally. The fact that I can set aside a little each month, even if it's just $50, gives me a sense of control and peace of mind. At the same time, thinking about my work schedule and the hours I put in reminded me of how much I've come to value flexibility and purpose in my job. It's not always easy, but I know that every hour I spend helping others is part of a larger journey—one that started with me being helped, and now I get to be the one who helps in return.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Matthew Gorman: Yes, my mother worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up, and in many ways, her work was what kept our family afloat during some of the toughest times. She was a teacher in Belgrade before we left for Germany, and even after we moved, she found ways to continue her work remotely or through local schools in Munich. She always emphasized the importance of education, and I think that's why she was so determined to keep working, even when we were in a foreign country with limited resources. My father, on the other hand, didn't have the same opportunities—he had only completed high school, and the war made it even harder for him to find steady work. But my mother never let that stop her. She took on extra classes, worked with other immigrant families to help them navigate the education system, and even started teaching Serbian to some of her students. I remember her telling me that she didn't want me to ever feel like my future was limited by where we came from. That belief in education and hard work is something I carry with me every day, and it's one of the reasons I chose to help others in the way I do now.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Matthew Gorman: My mother was a teacher, and even though she had to adapt to new environments multiple times, she never stopped believing in the power of education. In Belgrade, she taught elementary school, and she was known for her patience and creativity in the classroom. When we moved to Munich, she found work at a local school where they offered classes for immigrant children, which was a perfect fit for her skills. She would spend her days teaching, but she also took on extra responsibilities—helping other families understand the German education system, translating documents, and even organizing after-school programs for kids who were struggling to adjust. What I admired most about her was how she always found a way to give back, even when things were difficult. She once told me that teaching wasn't just about passing on knowledge—it was about giving people the tools to build a better life. That belief has stayed with me, and it's one of the reasons I chose to work in community outreach. I see my job as an extension of what she did, just in a different way. She taught children how to read and write; I try to teach people how to navigate a new world and find their place in it.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Matthew Gorman: My mother worked for a public school system in Belgrade, and later for a local school in Munich that served immigrant families. It was a small but impactful place, one where she could use her skills as an educator to help others, just as she had been helped when she was younger. She didn't make a lot of money, especially after we moved to Germany, but she always found ways to supplement her income—whether by teaching extra classes, offering tutoring services, or even translating documents for other families. What she made wasn't enough to live comfortably, but it was enough to keep us afloat and give me the chance to continue my education. I remember her working late into the night, grading papers or preparing lesson plans, all while trying to make sure we had food on the table. She never complained, and she never asked for anything more than what she had. That kind of dedication, that quiet strength, is something I carry with me every day. It's why I do what I do now—because I know what it's like to be in a place where you're not sure if you belong, and I want to make sure no one else has to feel that way.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Matthew Gorman: If I imagine myself a few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love, but with a little more stability and maybe even a bit more impact. I'd like to see the community center where I work grow into something bigger—something that can reach more people and provide even more resources to those who need them. I also hope to have the chance to visit Serbia more often, not just for short trips but for longer stays where I can reconnect with my roots and spend more time with my family. I want to be the kind of person who doesn't just help others survive but who helps them thrive. I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still finding ways to give back. Most of all, I hope I'm still believing in the power of second chances, because that's what got me here, and I want to make sure that belief never fades.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Matthew Gorman: What I value the most in my life is connection—whether it's the connection I feel with the people I work with, the relationships I've built with my friends like Carlos, or the deep bond I still have with my family in Serbia. I think, after everything I've been through, I've come to understand that no matter how far you go or how much you achieve, it's the people around you that give life its meaning. I also value resilience—the kind of resilience that comes from knowing you've been through hardship and still choosing to keep going. I value the ability to help others, to be that person who listens, who offers a hand, who reminds someone that they're not alone. And I value the quiet moments, the small things that ground me, like the smell of my mother's cooking or the sound of my sister's laughter over a video call. Those are the things that make life worth it, and I'm grateful for every one of them.

Going through the interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work and financial stability are intertwined with my sense of purpose and identity. Thinking about my monthly income and how I manage to make ends meet reminded me of how far I've come from those early days in Cleveland, when every dollar felt like a battle. It also made me realize how important it is to have a job that not only pays the bills but also aligns with my values and allows me to make a difference in people's lives. My relationship with my manager, Ms. Alvarez, and the sense of community I feel at work are things I wouldn't trade for anything. They remind me that I'm not just surviving—I'm thriving, and that's something I'm truly grateful for.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been both a journey of remembrance and rediscovery. It reminded me of how far I've come—from a child fleeing war in Belgrade to a community outreach coordinator in Cleveland, helping others navigate the same struggles I once faced. It also made me reflect on the people who shaped my path, like Ms. Alvarez, who gave me that first chance, and my mother, whose unwavering belief in education and hard work became the foundation of my own values. This process has shown me how deeply interconnected my past, present, and future are, and how every challenge, every small act of kindness, and every moment of resilience has brought me to where I am today. I'm grateful for the opportunity to share my story, not just as a record of my life, but as a reminder that no matter how uncertain the beginning, with courage, support, and a little bit of hope, it's possible to build a meaningful life and help others do the same.
